rComments: Great lecturer, tests are very specific to detail so you gotta work and study your butt off to get a good grade.

Good clarrity and enthusiasm. Lectures are a bit long, but what you learn in lectures is what is on the exam. Unless you don't listen and study, you shouldn't have a hard time in class. You can eaily pass the class if you put the effort.

Good proffessor. Very Clear and enthusiastic. Lectures are a bit long, but what you learn in lectures is what is on the exam. Unless you don't listen and study, you shouldn't have a hard time in class. You can eaily pass the class if you put the effort.

Good proffessor. Very Clear and enthusiastic. Lectures are a bit long, but what you learn is what you will be tested on. Unless you don't listen and study, you shouldn't have a hard time in class. You can eaily pass the class if you put the effort.

This class was a really good intro to earth science.  I thought the material would be more interesting, but all in all I still liked the stuff.  People think he asks too much when it comes to math, but really it's basic algebra, nothing to be scared off by.  Don't you have to take a few years of high school math to get into a UC anyways?  Take it!

He's a terrible professor. All his homework is irrelevant to the course. Went to every Intro to Weather and Climate class but never understood the homework assigned. For being an introductory course, he expects an advanced knowledge of chemistry and physics. I feel really bad for his TA's because they end up teaching most of the material.

Intro Weather/Climate. Cool class. Mathy, but if you're good at math/problem solving, it'll be a breeze. He has a difficult time communicating with people who aren't understanding the lower level parts of the class (i.e. algebra, basic chem/physics, etc), which isn't quite appropriate given there are no prerequisites for the class.

Patrik was a fun guy to talk to but not always the best during lecture. However, the class material was really interesting. But HARD! More math and applying math to concepts than expected. Hard to understand all topics. Must attend section and office hours regularly to do well.  Requires lots of work, but interesting. It my (possibly) new major.

Slightly rude, talks quickly without much clarity. the TA was more helpful than he was. When he left for about a month and a half, his substitute was more useful and effective than he was. I do not recommend taking this class. Im an Env. Sci maj. and this class made me rethink it.

I went to his office hours and he completely blew me off. ALOT of math in this class, definitely not what I expected. He brushes your questions off, and he is very drab. Wouldn't recommend the class if he's teaching it.

Had him for Weather and Climate and Environmentalism, both easily two of my favorite classes I've taken at UCSC. Pretty hard and lots of math and chem, but definitely  do-able for non-science majors. Pay attention and go to class, you'll do well. Makes me wish I was an Earth Sci. Major.

I thought this class would be an interesting class about environmentalism.  Instead it was about physics, and math, and had hardly anything to do with the environment.  Professor Chuang was a terrible lecturer, he never explained anything and made people who asked questions feel stupid.  DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS
One of the best professors I have ever had

Really difficult class if you're not good at math. I took this class thinking it would be interesting, and thinking I would learn more about environmentalism. Unfortunately, it was more science and math. In my opinion, the lectures were very boring. Only 1 TA for about 200 students. Midterm and final were difficult if you didn't attend optional sec

Class was no where near the course description.  Lots of chemistry, btu did not fufill the "Q" requirement.  Knew what he was talkign abotu for the most part.  Lectures pretty boring.  HARD homework and very hard tests. Hard grader. take a different class... this one isnt worth it. great ta
Interesting, really basically explains things. book not needed, FOLLOW LECTURES. ATTEND ALL LECTURES. DO HW. tests are fairly had but all questions given in advance! :-D
Used great example to explain things-demonstrations outdoors. Made the class more interesting.

DON'T DO IT!  I LOVE weather and watch tornadoe videos and watch the weather channel for fun so I figured this class would be  breeze considering I already know all there is to know about weather.  THIS CLASS WAS A LIE.  It was ALL math and HARD! It was fun ad interesting but difficult.  If you don't have a goodmath backgournd stay away

This is a very difficult class for students who do not do well in math.  This class ONLY gets rid of a IN but it should also cover a Q.  I struggled all throught this course.  There was only one T.A for four-hundred students and that made things more difficult.  Thirty students would show up for office hours, that was very rediculous.

This was supposed to be my gen ed "easy" class, but no! If you really hate math, you shouldn't be in the class because it's not as much conceptual as it is math. But he's a great professor. He explains well, but sometimes doesn't do examples and gives us very difficult homework problems.
Meant for non majors, but damn, it's hard.  I hate math, but Chuang guided me through, and let me pass.  What a nice guy!!!!!
Don't let the math scare you away, going to the optional sections is a must!  Overall the work corresponds to the lectures very well.  Nice professor, most people get better grades than anticipated.

Since it was meant for non-majors, I thought it would be an easy class. It wasn't. The homework was impossible to complete, unless you got help during the optional section. The tests were also very difficult. The topics were somewhat interesting at least.

The syllabus for Intro To Weather and Climate said 'for non math/science people'. Watch out. It's a big, fat lie. On the first day of teaching, he gives a long list of physics terms that become the backbone of the class. The Homework is IMPOSSIBLE.

The class was described as a science class for 'non-science/math people' however, on the second day of class he decided to give us an entire list of physics terms. All the homework has been math based. The tests are difficult and he's a picky grader.
